greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Filter combining sigma(n) with the parity of n; restricted growth sequence transform of ((-1)^n)*A000203(n).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537
example: For n = 21 and 31 the restricted growth sequence transform assigns the same value (we have a(21) = a(31) = 21) because both numbers are odd, and the sum of their divisors is equal as sigma(21) = sigma(31) = 32.
On the other hand, although sigma(14) = sigma(15) = 24, a(14) != a(15) because the other number is even and the other number is odd. Compare to A286603.
program: rgs_transform(invec) = { my(om = Map(), outvec = vector(length(invec)), u=1); for(i=1, length(invec), if(mapisdefined(om,invec[i]), my(pp = mapget(om, invec[i])); outvec[i] = outvec[pp] , mapput(om,invec[i],i); outvec[i] = u; u++ )); outvec; };
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 07 2017
